;;一连串缩写词从警车无线电中传来，激励尼克·比斯利采取行动。比斯利三十出头，当了九年警察，负责维护伦敦西部伊灵区的治安。那是 10 月一个阳光明媚的周五下午 4 点，我陪他和他的同事马拉奇·兰德尔 (Malachi Randell) 上夜班，玛拉奇·兰德尔是一位 20 多岁、身材瘦长的见习侦探。比斯利拉响了警报器，前面的汽车就弯曲开走了，仿佛被向心力推到了一边。我们转了几个弯，在一条安静的绿树成荫的街道上的一栋联排别墅外停了下来。三个穿着洞洞鞋、戴着头巾的女人站在开满紫色和杏色非洲雏菊的花园里。其中一人实事求是地说：“她走进客厅，砸坏了电视。”

;

;这名妇女此前曾因精神病在医院接受过治疗。这是警方三天内第三次来访。一小时前有人叫了救护车，但还没有出现。当天早些时候，国家医疗服务体系 (;NHS;) 的心理健康小组前来进行评估，但显然感到受到威胁并离开了。兰德尔给球队打电话询问他们是否可以回来。与他交谈的心理健康工作者说他们不能——他们需要去接孩子。

;

;;警察的主要职责之一就是应对患有心理健康危机的人，他们无法从 NHS 获得正确的支持。但大都会正在反击;

;

;大都会，即伦敦大都会警察局，从未如此繁忙。 4 月份，警方单日接到近 9,300 个紧急电话，创下新纪录。大都会专员马克·罗利指出，其中只有少数与犯罪有关。警察的主要职责之一已成为应对患有心理健康危机的人们，他们无法从;NHS;获得足够的支持。但大都会博物馆正在反击。从 11 月 1 日起，它希望将其官员响应的此类呼叫数量减少约三分之一。大都会表示，这将腾出时间来对付罪犯：3 月份的一份令人震惊的报告发现，目前警方只解决了 8% 的已报告犯罪。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;屋内，楼上的窗户里出现了一个人影，喊道：“你为什么要报警？”根据《精神健康法》第 136 条，如果警方认为为了个人或他人的安全有必要，警方有权紧急拘留某人最多 36 小时：每年大约有 7,000 人被大都会警察分拆。比斯利解释说，在这种情况下，他无权对这名妇女进行解剖，因为她是在自己家里，而且似乎有精神能力。在家人的允许下，比斯利护送她出去，她平静地离开了家。在我们都回到车上之前，他靠在花园的墙上，在笔记本电脑上输入了报告。

;;;;

;我们没走多远就接到电话，说那个女人回来了并威胁她家庭。这给了警方逮捕的理由。比斯利和兰德尔回来后，在屋外的街上给她戴上手铐。她躺在人行道上，无声地抗议，木屐从警察张开的双腿之间露出来。一辆警车抵达，两名警察跳下车，戴上蓝色乳胶手套，然后触碰了这名女子。他们试图拉着她的衣袖将她拉起来，但她瘫软在地，被动地反抗。他们四个人，一人扶住四肢，才把她抬进货车后部的笼子里。 （严格来说，救护车的目的是运送患有精神健康危机的人去医院，但救护车服务不堪重负，常常将责任推给警察。）

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;比斯利回到车上拿他的笔记本电脑。在他的警帽和浓密的赤褐色胡须之间，他的脸变成了粉红色。抓捕过程中，该女子声称一离开派出所就要自杀，因此警方决定对她进行剖腹产。她的家人也许已经筋疲力尽，似乎对她的命运漠不关心，从房子里出来只是把碎玻璃扫进垃圾桶。

;

;;警察对人群进行分区的权力是有争议的。它将精神疾病定为犯罪，黑人被分割的可能性几乎是白人的五倍。但警方常常认为他们别无选择。 “如果我没有对某人进行分类，而他们发生了一些事情，那就是我的错，”比斯利说。

;

;;警察对人进行分区的权力是有争议的。它将精神疾病定为犯罪，黑人被分尸的可能性是白人的五倍;

;

;一旦有人被分尸，警察就有义务将他们带到安全的地方，通常是事故发生地和最近医院的急诊 (;A&E;) 部门，并留在他们身边，直到他们的心理健康状况得到评估。由于 ;NHS; 正处于崩溃边缘，这可能需要一段时间——在护理转移之前，官员们平均要在 ;A&E; 等待分诊病人 14.2 小时。在整个英格兰，警察每年的工作时间加起来不到 100 万小时。 “有时候，医院看起来就像一个警察院子，”比斯利说。

;

;他说，现在警察会因一般的医疗紧急情况而出动。 “我们被派去治疗癫痫和中风的患者……我们接受的训练很少。”他说，最近，他被要求将一名流血的孕妇送往医院。他拒绝了，因为“这是救护车服务的工作。他们不会把它交给消防队，那为什么是我们呢？”比斯利支持大都会减少其响应的心理健康呼吁数量的决定。他说：“我们现在反击说，我们是警察。”

;;;;

;我们在傍晚的细雨中跟随载着被肢解的妇女的货车来到医院，一名穿着手术服的男子正在那里等待把她带走接受监视。现在心情平静了一些，她自愿下了车。仅仅 15 分钟就为她找到了床位。 “这真是奇迹，”兰德尔说道，对移交的轻松程度感到惊讶。

;

;从 11 月 1 日起，此类移交将会减少。仅当发生犯罪或存在直接生命威胁时（呼叫处理人员将做出判断），大都会才会对事件做出反应。警方将更加严格地执行现有准则，例如，依靠救护车而不是警车将人们送往医院。由警方和英国国家医疗服务体系 (NHS) 运营的专门求助热线将为伦敦警察提供有关何时对某人进行分区的建议。明年春天，;NHS; 将为公众推出另一条求助热线，旨在为任何遭受心理健康危机困扰的人提供单一呼叫点。

;

;大都会博物馆有信心尽管比斯利对此表示怀疑，但这些变化将释放军官更多的时间。 “我认为这不会产生巨大的影响，但呼叫负载会下降，”他说。当英格兰北部亨伯赛德警方在 2019 年采取类似方法时，报警总数下降了 8%，心理健康报警下降了三分之一。两年之内，犯罪率下降，与全国趋势相反。

;

;;从 11 月开始，只有在发生犯罪或存在直接生命威胁的情况下，大都会才会对事件做出反应;

;

;在当前系统中， “伦敦人已经失败了两次，”负责大都会艺术博物馆处理心理健康问题的侦探总监阿拉斯泰尔·范纳 (Alastair Vanner) 说。他说，有心理健康危机的人会被当作罪犯对待，但犯罪受害者也会遭受痛苦。目前，由于时间紧迫，警方不再对大多数入店行窃的举报做出回应。平均来说，大都会博物馆需要两个小时来应对入室盗窃和抢劫，是 2018 年的两倍。

;

;当大都会博物馆停止运作时，尚不清楚患有心理健康危机的伦敦人会发生什么。出来对付他们。 ;NHS;不会有额外的资金来应对额外的工作量。心理健康团队的工作人员常常精疲力尽，已经无法满足焦虑、抑郁和自杀倾向的人的需求。救护车到达心脏病或中风患者的时间是目标时间的两倍。理想情况下，警察不应该成为医疗紧急情况的第一反应者，但如果没有他们，遇险的人可能会遭受比其他人更糟糕的命运。

;;;;

;回到巡逻车里，心理健康呼吁中出现了短暂的插曲当比斯利和兰德尔得知一些青少年在公园里放火时。他们在黑暗中踩过水洼，发现了两名穿着连帽衫的 14 岁男孩，但没有看到火焰。他们在泳池派对上实施纵火袭击的机会比在这场雨中更好。 “你怎么这么高？”他们问身高 6 英尺 5 英寸的兰德尔。 “吃你的蔬菜，”他说。

;

;我们带着外卖汉堡和薯条回到警察局，当接到电话通知比斯利和兰德尔另一名年轻女子患有精神病时，这些东西都被扔掉了。官员们说，英国国家医疗服务体系（NHS）的一个危机小组让她吃药，然后就“滚蛋了”。家人叫了救护车，但救护车服务部门将工作转交给了警方。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;另一辆巡逻车在我们之前到达。这名女子穿着一件粗呢大衣坐在自家的楼梯上，戴着手铐，以免她的头撞到墙上。一个小时后，比斯利和兰德尔说服她去医院。当她被扶上警车前部时，一辆救护车到达了。警车最终没有再次移动她，而是带走了她。让我惊讶的是，处理 999 电话的调度员就像傀儡师，为不同的事件部署不同的紧急服务，就像戏剧中的人物和场景一样。但木偶的线经常会缠结在一起。目前尚不清楚限制警察的职责将如何改善紧急服务部门之间明显缺乏沟通的情况。

;

;;当大都会博物馆停止接听电话时，患有心理健康危机的伦敦人会发生什么，这一点不太确定。 NHS将不会有额外的资金来处理额外的工作量;

;

;车上，电话声继续响起。蓝光冲刺寻找高风险失踪人员在另一支警察首先联系到他后，这名在社交媒体上发布自杀遗书的人被取消了联系。晚上 9.30 左右，比斯利梦想着在大都会的狗部门工作，他确定一只名叫 Candy 的看似友善的 ;XL; 恶霸犬并没有达到危险狗的门槛（在一系列攻击之后，英国即将禁止该品种）。警察无视了另一通电话，该电话是警方认识的一名女子打来的，她发誓要用剃须刀割伤自己。 “我们去过很多次，但说实话，她只是很孤独，祝福她，”比斯利说。

;

;还有时间进行最后一次通话。我们把车开进一条小巷，看到一个男人坐在毯子里瑟瑟发抖，脸上还盖着一条血迹斑斑的毛巾。在一次看似随机的袭击中，他的嘴唇被一名陌生人咬伤，然后袭击者的女友用砖头猛击他的头部。当警察展开蓝白相间的胶带时，一辆货车内发生了一阵混乱，其中一名嫌疑犯向比斯利吐口水。他的轮班晚了一个小时，但他仍然留下来听取多名证人的证词。这似乎正是警方所渴望的：有更多时间逮捕真正的罪犯。 ;■;

;

;;;;未来是电动的。这意味着它将需要大量的电池、电机和电线。反过来，这意味着制造它们需要大量的钴、铜、锂和镍。那么，对于探矿者来说，尤其是对于那些认为自己可以提高职业效率的人来说，这是一个伟大的时代。一些公司正在将;人工智能; (;AI;)应用到这个过程中，以提高成功的几率。地表撞击并探测当前技术看不见的地下矿体。

;

;加利福尼亚州伯克利的 KoBold Metals、旧金山的 Earth ;AI ; 和 Ver;AI; >; 目前，波士顿的 SensOre 和布里斯班的 OreFox 也是如此。但至少有一条更大的鱼——澳大利亚-英国公司——力拓集团——也很热衷。他们正在收集大量地质、地球化学和地球物理数据来输入软件模型。他们希望这些能够发现模式并推断在何处埋设新地雷。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;一些数据是新的。但很多东西曾经在国家地质调查档案、地质期刊和其他历史资料库中腐烂，或者以力拓为例，该公司已经运营了 150 年，以岩芯的形式存放在世界各地的各个棚屋中。世界。

;

;狗头人是神秘的地下精灵，困扰着中世纪德国的矿工。 （他们也给钴起了自己的名字。）KoBold 的老板库尔特·豪斯 (Kurt House) 希望他们的一些魔力能够发挥作用。他的公司将来自世界各地的档案数据重新格式化为机器可用的形式，其中许多是纸质的，其中一些可以追溯到 19 世纪。这使得它能够绘制整个地球表面感兴趣区域的地图。

;

;其中一些地图用于训练该公司的;AI;模型。另一些则用于测试该软件的有效性，方法是检查它在以前从未见过的地图上预测已知矿床的效果。如果它通过了，它可以被释放到尚未探索的感兴趣的地方，为 KoBold 的地质学家提供线索。

;

;Earth ;AI;，由 Roman Teslyuk 领导，SensOre，由 Richard 领导Taylor 和沃里克·安德森 (Warwick Anderson) 领导的 OreFox 也采取了类似的方法，但重点关注拥有特别丰富的公共地质记录的澳大利亚。 Ver;AI; 由 Yair Frastai 领导，专注于北美和南美西部地区，世界十大铜矿中的八个都位于该地区。

;

;豪斯博士对他的;人工智能;预测地下深成侵入体的形状和分布的能力感到特别自豪。这些是火成岩体，通常含有矿石，它们作为液态岩浆从地球内部升起，但在到达地表之前就凝固了。它们可以通过磁异常从地表检测到，磁异常表明一组特定的岩石是在与其周围环境不同的时间形成的，这是行业的标准做法。但 KoBold 的 ;AI; 能够更准确地预测这些入侵的形状，从而建议最有效的钻探位置。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;并取得成功。去年，KoBold 宣布在赞比亚发现了丰富的辉铜矿（一种铜的硫化物）矿藏。与此同时，Earth ;AI; 在新南威尔士州发现了大量钼（特种钢的重要组成部分）。 Ver;AI;在智利和秘鲁发现了含有铜、金和银的矿石。 SensOre 在西澳大利亚发现了大量锂矿。 OreFox 的技术在维多利亚州发现了一个潜在的金矿，以及几个有前景的铜矿前景。

;

;力拓正在建设其勘探数据科学主管 Russell Eley 所说的“虚拟岩心棚”。这将汇集该公司多年来收集的许多岩心样本的详细信息。然后，软件将搜索这些模式，以帮助解释新的岩心，并告诉地质学家下一步钻探的最佳地点。

;

;House 博士观察到，99% 的勘探项目未能变成真正的矿山。因此，;AI;还有很大的改进空间。它还可能有助于解决更微妙的问题。通过大幅扩大可搜寻的岩石数量，它将能够在熟悉的、治理良好的国家进行新的打击，从而减少未来供应对泰勒先生在外交上所称的“外国司法管辖区”的依赖。 ;■;

;;我;;在试图;规划未来时，世界领导人正在回顾过去。 “当这场危机结束后，必须对接下来的情况有一个愿景，在我们看来，这必须是两国解决方案，”经济学家乔·拜登说。 com/briefing/2023/10/24/the-overstretched-superpower">;美国总统;在他关于加沙近一个月战争的众多公开声明中的其中一个。英国首相里希·苏纳克(Rishi Sunak)也发表了类似言论。法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙(Emmanuel Macron)也是如此。上个月阿拉伯联盟召开紧急会议，呼吁就两国解决方案进行“认真谈判”。

;
;

;;阅读我们对以色列和哈马斯之间战争的所有报道;

;
;

;以色列离开时;2005 年，加沙;将大约 8,000 名犹太定居者从自 1967 年以来一直控制的领土上赶了出来，没有人知道该做什么做出决定。一些人希望以色列放弃被占领土的意愿将成为一种趋势，成为与巴勒斯坦人达成最终解决方案的一步。其他人看到了一个精明的策略：放弃对加沙的控制可能有助于以色列巩固对约旦河西岸的控制。后一种观点被证明是正确的。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;自 10 月份以来，类似的困惑也出现了7日，以色列开始计划;对加沙进行地面入侵;。巴勒斯坦人担心这场战争将导致第二次“灾难”，指的是 1948 年以色列诞生时伴随的大规模流离失所。以色列极右翼部长希望这将提供一个重新控制巴勒斯坦领土的机会。加沙并重建被拆除的犹太人定居点。一些充满希望的人，其中包括拜登先生，希望这将为重振陷入昏迷的以色列-巴勒斯坦和平进程提供机会。

;

;目前，这是一个遥远的梦想：以色列将军预计将持续数月的战斗。但他们和许多外国势力都希望最终将加沙的控制权移交给巴勒斯坦权力机构（<小>;pa;），该权力机构管理西岸部分地区，可能会派出一支维和部队来帮助过渡。他们怀疑巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯是否会在没有保证就巴勒斯坦建国问题进行有意义的谈判的情况下返回加沙。

;

;换句话说，加沙“后天”的任何计划都需要考虑两国解决方案的可能性。几十年来，总体轮廓没有太大变化。加沙和约旦河西岸将建立巴勒斯坦国；以色列将用其大片领土交换其在西岸建立大型定居点的部分地区。耶路撒冷将被分割，旧城将受到某种形式的联合控制。少数巴勒斯坦难民可能会返回以色列，而其余的人将在巴勒斯坦或其他地方目前的家园定居。以色列希望巴勒斯坦国实现非军事化。

;

;经过二十年的认真谈判——从 20 世纪 90 年代初奥斯陆协议的充满希望的时代，到巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 领导下的断断续续的尝试——和平进程终于实现了。 2014 年暂停。此后就没有进行过认真的谈判。

;

;谈判人员无法完全从中断的地方继续。截至 2021 年底，西岸居住着 465,400 名以色列定居者，而 1993 年签署奥斯陆协议时这一数字为 116,300 人。他们日益成为和平的障碍。大多数人集中在可能会在协议中割让给以色列的地区，但他们的政治影响力（他们甚至反对放弃他们不居住的土地）随着人口的增加而增加。

;

;背景是一切

;

;区域情况也更加复杂。 2002年，阿拉伯联盟批准了沙特的一项提议，承诺在两国解决方案后以色列与阿拉伯国家建立正常关系：通过结束与巴勒斯坦的冲突，以色列可以结束其所有地区冲突。阿拉伯和平倡议旨在成为一个强大的诱因。如果以色列认为其他威胁会消失，它可能更愿意摆脱巴勒斯坦人。

;

;但该地区自 2002 年以来已经发生了变化。一些民兵，来自 ;黎巴嫩真主党;到也门胡塞武装，现在比他们称之为家乡的国家更强大。 It would not suffice for Arab governments to end their conflicts with Israel: non-state actors would have to agree to do so as well.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Other things could be easier.两国解决方案代价高昂。甚至在战争之前，巴勒斯坦人就希望得到帮助来恢复加沙；现在账单会高得多。在 2000 年失败的戴维营峰会上，谈判代表讨论了一项 300 亿美元的基金，以补偿巴勒斯坦难民的财产损失。 Gulf states such as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates (;uae;), which have boosted ties with Israel in recent years, might be more willing to stump up the cash to show they have not abandoned the Palestinians.

;

;The biggest problem, however, remains not the details of a solution but the political will to negotiate and implement one. There will be no serious peace process with ;Binyamin Netanyahu's; coalition of far-right and religious politicians.加沙战争结束后，这个联盟不太可能长期存在，内塔尼亚胡的反对者希望下一届政府能够更愿意与巴勒斯坦人进行谈判。一位以色列中间派议员表示：“我们吸取了教训，我们需要以一种好的方式与他们分开。” “是时候开始讨论了。” But Israeli politicians from the centre and left have avoided the issue in public for more than a decade.

;

;On the Palestinian side, Hamas has always been eager to play spoiler. Its first suicide-bombings in the 1990s helped to scuttle the Oslo process, and the carnage it wrought during the second ;intifada; (“uprising”) from 2000 to 2005 turned a generation of Israelis against the idea of compromise. Perhaps Hamas will fade away after the war in Gaza—but another group could take its place.

;

;Ordinary people on both sides have lost faith in the two-state solution.无党派智囊团以色列民主研究所 2022 年 9 月的一项民意调查发现，只有 32% 的以色列犹太人支持这一计划，低于五年前的 47%。 Israeli Arabs, who make up one-fifth of the population, still endorsed the idea, although their support has also dropped, from 87% in 2017 to 71% in 2022. A plurality of Israeli Jews preferred the status quo.

;

;Support has plummeted even further among; Palestinians;.巴勒斯坦政策和调查研究中心 2023 年 6 月的一项调查发现，只有 28% 的人仍然支持两国解决方案。 Some 53% of them backed the idea ten years ago, though just 39% thought it feasible.

;

;Optimists hope that these results are squishy: people are unlikely to support something they think impossible.有意义的和平进程可能会推动民意调查数字回升。 “我认为我们的人民不会拒绝结束占领的机会，”一位前巴勒斯坦部长表示。 But the events of recent weeks could just as well harden both sides against the idea of compromise.

;

;As ever in Israel, some of the strongest supporters of ending the occupation are the men tasked with running it.哈马斯袭击事件发生后，很少有以色列人公开谈论两国解决方案或任何其他冲突解决方案。但国防部官员正在封闭的房间里讨论这个问题。 That is partly because the desired end state of the war will shape the war itself and because the Netanyahu government is incapable of holding a serious debate on Israel's long-term strategy.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Then there is the question of who will play mediator.尽管俄罗斯和中国都渴望在中东和平中发挥作用，但两国都没有太多的影响力或信誉来承担这一角色。 The European Union could position itself as an honest broker but it is not taken seriously.

;

;That leaves America.拜登在担任总统的头三年里一直试图忽视这场冲突。 2024 年，他还会考虑其他事情——以色列人和巴勒斯坦人都不太可能与一位可能很快被赶下台的总统启动和平进程。 If Mr Biden wins in 2024, he could try to lead efforts.

;

;Donald Trump would be another story. 2020 年 1 月，在对他的女婿贾里德·库什纳 (Jared Kushner) 制定的一项看似严肃的和平计划进行多年跟踪后，他终于公布了该计划。这个几乎可笑地偏向以色列的计划在抵达时就夭折了。巴勒斯坦人只能获得被占领的约旦河西岸 75% 的土地，这三个州有高速公路相连。以色列将保留约旦河谷这一领土的粮仓，并通过割让内盖夫几片贫瘠的沙漠来补偿巴勒斯坦人的损失。巴勒斯坦的首都将仅限于东耶路撒冷的几个贫困郊区。不出所料，巴勒斯坦人甚至拒绝讨论该提议。 ;■;

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 00:57:02 +0800 Do Labour’s plans for Britain’s private schools make sense? | Britainhttps://www.economist.com/britain/2023/10/31/do-labours-plans-for-britains-private-schools-make-sense ;
;
;

;;F;;or decades;, on and off, the Labour Party has been promising to take a harder line on private, fee-paying schools. Before the general election in 2019 it pledged to explore ways of “integrating” them into the public sector. That idea has been dropped, along with one to strip private schools of their charitable status.

;

;But the policies spelled out to enthusiastic applause at Labour's conference in October—to make private-school fees subject to value-added tax (;VAT);, at the standard rate of 20%, and to remove a discount these schools receive on business rates—are still controversial. Given the party's yawning lead in the polls, they are also likely to become reality. As claims and counterclaims fly, three questions dominate. What is the case for making the tax changes? Would they materially affect private schools? And would they improve education in Britain?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;On the rationale for the policy, Sir Keir Starmer, Labour's leader, has batted away claims that his party is contemptuous of aspirational parents; he has said he sees “no case” for trying to abolish fee-paying schools. Instead Labour's argument is that it is unjust to continue exempting from tax a service bought mostly by the rich.

;

;Research suggests that pupils in private schools learn more than they would if they studied in the state sector. Indeed, the fact that they get more and better qualifications is the biggest single reason they earn more than others in adulthood, according to academics at University College London (;UCL;) and Cambridge. (Chummy networks probably also help.) By the time they turn 25, privately educated Britons earn 17% more than workers from similar homes, according to research published in 2020. The pay premium widens by the age of 42, according to earlier research, to around 21% for women and 35% for men.

;
;;

;About three-quarters of children in Britain's private schools come from the richest 30% of families, according to another study by academics at ;UCL;. In contrast, only 2% of pupils come from the poorest third of families (see chart). Although private schools sometimes offer means-tested discounts aimed at drawing in poorer children, last year only about 7% of private-school pupils benefited. Of this small group, only about half received help amounting to 50% or more of total costs; only about one-quarter attended free.

;

;Critics say that the “partnerships” private schools boast of forming with state schools are underwhelming, sometimes involving little more than matches between their sports teams. It is also occasionally argued that private schools deprive government ones of wealthy and engaged parents. And according to Francis Green at ;UCL;, private schools educate less than 7% of pupils in England but employ around 14% of teachers.

;

;Private schools push back. They object in particular to Labour's claims that they are benefiting from “tax breaks”. Most education spending is exempted from consumption taxes, on the principle that encouraging adults to invest in youngsters' brains will benefit the country in the long run. Parents do not pay ;VAT; when they send toddlers to playgroups; undergraduates never pay ;VAT; on their tuition fees (even though degrees can greatly boost their incomes). Julie Robinson of the Independent Schools Council (;ISC;), a group representing more than half of Britain's 2,400 or so private schools, says it is rare for countries to tax school fees, and that if Britain were still in the ;EU; it would not be allowed.

;
;

;Fee or free

;

;Private schools also complain that debates about the sector focus on a handful of very toffee-nosed institutions, such as Eton, and on a subset of parents seeking a shortcut to Oxbridge. In fact, plenty of parents have turned to private schools in the hope that extra help might turn a struggling schoolchild into an average one. And lots of private schools offer specific educational or religious environments that are not available in the state sector. Lizzy Nesbitt, the principal of Emmanuel Christian School, a private primary with 60 pupils in Oxford that charges annual fees of about £6,500 ($7,900), thinks her school's families—about one-third of whom earn £40,000 or less—are probably not the kind that Labour is imagining it is targeting.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The second debate is what the effects of changing the tax rules would be. The; ISC; insists the impact of adding ;VAT; to school fees would be huge. A report it commissioned in 2018, when such a policy was last widely discussed, claimed that private-school enrolment could fall by 17-25% in the five years following; some 90,000-135,000 additional pupils would enter state schools. Competition for spots in the best government schools would inflate house prices in their catchment areas; adding lots of spots to the state system would cost money. Labour says it will raise £1.7bn from its plan; the ;ISC;'s study warned that the reform might raise little extra cash.

;

;There is good reason to think the consequences would be much less dramatic. The Institute for Fiscal Studies (;IFS;), a think-tank, argues that there is only a very weak relationship between the cost of private schooling and the number of parents who pay for it. Average private-school fees, now £15,200 a year, have jumped by 20% in real terms since 2010 and by 55% since 2003, for reasons unrelated to the government. Over that time the share of all children who are educated privately has barely budged. Private-school parents are increasingly concentrated in very high-earning professions such as finance, goes one explanation; fees are also more likely to be paid in part or in full by rich grandparents.

;

;The ;IFS;'s best guess is that adding ;VAT; to fees would cause private-school enrolment to fall by 3-7% (up to 40,000 kids) over several years. It thinks the policy would raise about £1.3bn-1.5bn for the government—equal to about 2% of the state-school budget. Unlike other analysts, it argues that parents who stop paying school fees will probably end up spending the money they save on other things, most of which would be taxed. So even if as many as 15% of pupils shifted, the change would still raise about £1bn.

;

;Again, however, the impact is likely to be unevenly distributed. About half of private schools have fewer than 290 pupils; a quarter have fewer than 155. Even modest swings in enrolment could hit these fairly hard. The largest and most elite schools may be less affected. Businesses that charge ;VAT; are exempt from paying the tax on their own “inputs”; the greatest beneficiaries would be schools that spend the most on things other than teachers' pay, including luxuries such as golf courses.

;

;The final question is what scale of improvements Labour can drive in the state sector with the extra tax receipts. So far it has promised to spend £350m hiring 6,500 more teachers, which would swell the state-school workforce by around 1%. It talks of spending a similar amount providing breakfast clubs in primary schools, which some evidence suggests can boost how much the littlest pupils learn.

;

;A vaguer list of uncosted aspirations contains nothing anyone could find offensive but may not drive big improvements. Labour has rejected the government's proposal that all pupils study maths until 18; its alternative idea, to keep improving maths teaching in the early primary years, seems both less ambitious and less responsive to what international data suggest are currently schools' biggest flaws.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;During the years of Conservative rule England's schools have drifted up international league tables. That has probably had less to do with funding—which has too often been miserly—than with unpopular reforms to curriculums and tests. Pushing up standards in the state sector has made it gradually harder for private-school pupils to win places on the most prestigious degree courses. That, as well as efforts by elite universities to increase their state-school intake, may be a bigger threat to fee-paying schools than any change in tax rules.

;

;Arguments, in other words, are being over-egged on all sides. Private schools will lose some pupils but fewer than they claim, especially among their core constituency of rich parents. Labour will draw a bit of cash from rich parents and please a lot of its voters, but the most-affected private schools and parents are likely to be smaller and less wealthy, respectively. The money raised will be useful at the margins but it will not fix the biggest issues in schools. The signals sent by this issue arouse passions; its actual importance is less great. ;■;

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 00:27:03 +0800 “King Lear” and the purpose of tragedy in dark times | Culturehttps://www.economist.com/culture/2023/11/01/king-lear-and-the-purpose-of-tragedy-in-dark-times ;
;
;

;;M;;urder on the; television, agony on the radio;互联网上的谎言和仇恨，还有你在意识到自己的错误之前点击的鼻烟视频。这个星球是一个沸腾的大锅，而你是其​​中一只自鸣得意的青蛙。 When the real world feels like a charnel house, why spend an evening and a chunk of cash watching bodies pile up on stage?

;

;And in “King Lear”, ;Shakespeare; piles them high. “That's but a trifle here,” a character says of another's demise during the final die-in.; But the play—and Sir Kenneth Branagh's ingenious new production in London—make a powerful case for subjecting yourself to ;tragic art;, even at a time of surround-sound horror.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;These days “King Lear” is performed less often than “Hamlet”, with its startlingly acute psychology, or “Othello” and ;“Macbeth”;, with their overtly modern themes of race, misogyny and the corrupting effects of power.评论家经常认为《李尔王》是哲学诗歌的胜利，但作为戏剧来说却是不切实际的。 There is just too much of it, and too much in it: too many ideas and emotions, too many stories and, above all, too much desolation and despair.

;

;The evil characters destroy one another, but they take the good down with them.爱会杀人；人不过是“可怜的、光秃秃的、分叉的动物”。在整个 18 世纪，这种凄凉似乎是如此令人震惊，甚至是不道德的，以至于《李尔王》的结局被修改为幸福的结局。观众仍然在与情绪超负荷作斗争。 A decade ago, at another vaunted production in London, people sniggered when they were meant to weep.

;

;Sir Kenneth, a British ;actor and director;, stars in and directs the version that opened at the Wyndham's Theatre on October 31st. （该剧将于 2024 年在纽约的 Shed 上演。）他对这部剧的规模做出的部分反应是删减了很多内容。这是两个小时的精彩悲剧，故事背景大胆地以新石器时代的英国为背景，中间没有冰淇淋和八卦的间隙。身穿兽皮、挥舞长矛的演员们围绕着一个让人想起巨石阵的荒凉布景，他们的脸间歇性地以非新石器时代的投影出现在石头上。 Above them hangs an orb resembling both a planet and an eyeball, which sometimes seems to bleed.

;

;Here the power struggle that follows Lear's division of his kingdom is less a clash of armies than a scrap for a bauble in the mud.然而，没有盛况也让故事核心的家庭戏剧显得非常亲密和熟悉。肯尼思爵士饰演的李尔被敌人抓住，双手被绑在背后，他用胡子擦干心爱的女儿科迪莉亚（杰西卡·雷维尔饰）的眼泪。很快，他把她的尸体抬到了舞台上，悲伤地嚎叫着。 this time, nobody laughed.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;They chuckled at other moments though, as Sir Kenneth judiciously keeps and hones the funny bits to help the philosophy go down.这不仅仅是荒诞疯狂和闹剧折磨的幽默，徘徊在悲情和嘲笑之间，通常被称为“怪诞喜剧”。 There is also the comedy of charismatic devilment and gullibility, of champion wordplay and some of Shakespeare's most colourful insults.

;

;As for the purpose of tragedy: Edgar (Doug Colling) implies one as he drags his blind and suicidal father Gloucester (Joseph Kloska) across ancient Britain. “人们必须忍受/他们离开这里，就像他们来到这里一样，”他宣扬道。 “成熟就是一切。”换句话说，人生就是一场耐力考验。 It follows that, for viewers, tragic art is a kind of practice in grinning and bearing it.

;

;We have had quite enough practice in that, today's punters may think;对斯多葛主义的说教会产生一种自以为是的道德观。然而，埃德加的结论并不是戏剧的结论。它为痛苦场面提供的理由不仅仅是耐心的教训，甚至比肯尼思爵士那样出色的行为所能提供的在苦难中的团结感更重要。

;

;“King Lear” is full of audiences: characters who witness folly, misery or cruelty and must choose what to do about them.有些人权衡自己的利益并加入进来。有些人则束手无策。 A few resist, such as the heroic servant who objects as Cornwall (a sinister Hughie O'Donnell) rips out Gloucester's eyes in a spasm of bloodlust and impunity.

;

;It is hard to imagine yourself as Lear, even one as denuded as Sir Kenneth's.但也许你可以像那些默默无闻的小人物一样，选择行动而不是仅仅观看。 “哦，你们是石头人，”国王在结尾时哭喊着，要求幸存的角色和观众对不公正现象给予更大的同情。剧中呼吁，不要只是坐在那里。做一点事。 ;■;

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 23:27:02 +0800 Why doctors in America earn so much | United Stateshttps://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/10/31/why-doctors-in-america-earn-so-much ;
;
;

;;A;;ccording to the; Association of American Medical Colleges (;AAMC;), in a decade America will have a shortage of up to 124,000 doctors.这毫无意义。这个职业的薪酬很高：根据芝加哥大学经济学家 Joshua Gottlieb 及其同事最近发表的一篇论文，平均工资为 35 万美元。很多人想接受医生培训：每年有超过 85,000 人参加医学院入学考试，超过一半的医学院申请者被拒绝。但医生仍然短缺。 What is going on?

;
;;

;For many Americans, the ;doctor shortage; has already arrived.如今，有超过 1 亿人生活在没有足够初级保健医生的地区（这个问题在农村地区尤其严重）。对于心理健康而言，情况更糟：一半的美国人生活在心理健康专业人员短缺的地区。 With less than three physicians for every 1,000 people, America is behind most other wealthy countries, despite spending vastly more on health care (see chart).

;

;The usual suspects have been blamed.随着婴儿潮一代的年龄增长，对医疗保健的需求增加，他们中的医生也退休了。 According to the ;AAMC;, more than two out of five practising doctors will be 65 or older within the next decade, leaving even more vacancies. Covid-19 drove doctors away: an analysis by Peterson-;KFF;, a non-profit group, shows that health-care workers are quitting their jobs at a rate 30% higher than before covid (and about double the rate of all workers today). “大多数医生不会鼓励我们的后代进入医疗保健领域，”美国医学会主席兼医生杰西·埃伦菲尔德 (Jesse Ehrenfeld) 说。 “People have lost the joy in the profession.”

;

;Yet there is another explanation for the doctor shortage, which has to do with the pipeline into the profession, and which the American Medical Association has played a part in creating.在美国培训一名医生比在大多数富裕国家需要更长的时间，而且许多人中途放弃了。未来的医生必须首先从大学毕业，通常需要四年时间。然后他们必须再上医学院四年。 （在大多数其他富裕国家，医生需要大约六年的学校教育。）完成高等教育后，美国医生必须完成住院医师计划，该计划可以持续三到七年。随后可能会进行进一步的专业培训。 In all, it takes 10-15 years after arriving at university to become a doctor in America.

;

;If the expense and length of the training were not off-putting enough, the number of places in the profession has also been artificially held down. In September 1980 the Department of Health and Human Services released a report warning of a troubling surplus of 70,000 physicians by 1990 in most specialties.它建议减少进入医学院的人数，并建议限制外国医学院毕业生入境。 Despite the shortage, doctors trained abroad must still sit exams and complete a residency in most states regardless of their years of experience.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Medical colleges listened, and matriculation flatlined for 25 years, despite applications rising and the population growing by 70m over the same period (see chart). 1997年，联邦对住院医师的资助受到限制，迫使医院要么限制项目，要么承担部分培训医生的经济负担。一些景点已被添加回来，但还远远不够。 Many potential doctors are being shut out of the profession. “Not everyone who would be willing to go through that training and could do it successfully is being allowed to,” says Professor Gottlieb, the economist.

;

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 22:27:02 +0800 Why urban warfare in Gaza will be bloodier than in Iraq | Middle East & Africahttps://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/10/30/why-urban-warfare-in-gaza-will-be-bloodier-than-in-iraq ;
;
;

;;T;;HE WAR; in Gaza is exacting a brutal toll on civilians. The Hamas-run health ministry says that more than 8,000 people have ;died;. The number of children among them, more than 3,000, exceeds the annual death toll for children in all wars in each of the preceding three years. ;The Economist; ;estimates;, from satellite imagery, that over a tenth of Gaza's housing stock has been destroyed, leaving more than 280,000 people without homes to which they can return. In many ways that fits with the norm of urban warfare, which is unusually destructive. But Israel's war in Gaza is also distinctive.

;
;

;;;Read all our coverage of the war between Israel and Hamas;;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;War in built-up areas is always bloody. America's first assault on Fallujah in 2004 killed as many as 600 civilians, or 0.2% of the population, compared with 0.3% in today's war in Gaza. A second assault later in the year killed around 800 more and left the majority of the city's buildings damaged. A battle for Sadr City, a suburb of Baghdad, is thought to have killed nearly 1,000 people in March and April 2008, out of a population of around 2m, not dissimilar to that of Gaza.

;

;The largest urban battle in recent years was the assault on the city of ;Mosul;, which had been seized by the Islamic State (;IS;) group, by an American-led coalition including Iraqi and Kurdish ground forces. At least 9,000 civilians were killed in Mosul during 2016-17, according to Airwars, a non-profit organisation that tracks civilian harm. That amounts to 0.6% of the population at the time. Of the buildings that were damaged, more than 80% were residential.

;

;These cases might suggest that the ;war in Gaza;, though destructive, is not unusually so by historical standards—at least not yet. Yet there are also key differences. The first and biggest is the status of civilians. In Mosul, ;IS; attempted to prevent civilians from fleeing, firing at them and mining corridors out of the city. Many left nonetheless. Between October 2016 and June 2017 nearly 900,000 departed—almost half of the pre-war population. Even Russia, during its siege of Mariupol in Ukraine between February and May 2022, negotiated humanitarian pauses in which some civilians were permitted to leave. Israel has thus far rejected calls, by the European Union and others, for such pauses.

;

;;Gaza's geography; is less permissive than any of these cases. Israel has told around 1.1m civilians to evacuate from the north of Gaza, but around a third of those have remained in place. Many residents are already refugees from other places and fear that if they leave they might never be allowed to return to their homes. Those who do want to escape cannot go south to ;Egypt;, which does not want to take responsibility for refugees and has so far refused to open its border.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Israel is still striking parts of southern Gaza, albeit in more limited fashion than the north. “Locals can't really get away, nor can fighting really occur in open areas away from urban centres,” says Amos Fox, an expert on urban warfare who has written extensively about Mosul. “The urban fight [in Gaza] is self-contained and likely far more costly than anything we've seen in the past few years.” Even those civilians who have moved south face a growing humanitarian crisis. Gaza's health-care system has capacity for only 3,500 beds, according to Médecins Sans Frontières, a humanitarian group, far short of what is needed.

;

;In Mosul, by contrast, the World Health Organisation was able to establish trauma stabilisation points to provide urgent medical attention within 10-15 minutes of the front line, with larger field hospitals another hour away. The Israel Defence Forces (;IDF;) have a small number of “humanitarian affairs officers” embedded in its fighting units whose role it is to try and address the needs of the local population, but these are far from sufficient for dealing with the needs and scale of misery resulting from a ground offensive. Israeli politicians have said they will not send aid for civilians until all hostages are released, though officials acknowledge that may change as the offensive develops.

;

;A second difference is the degree to which civilian and military infrastructure is intermingled in Gaza. In Iraq, ;IS; had held Mosul for little over two years when the battle to remove them began. Even in that short period, the group had established impressive multi-layered defences, drawing on Western military doctrine, says Rupert Jones, a retired British major-general who was deputy commander of the anti-;IS; coalition.

;

;;Hamas;, in contrast, was founded in Gaza in 1987 and has much earlier roots there, dating back to the foundation of the welfare organisation Mujama al-Islamiya ('Islamic Centre”) by Ahmed Yassin in 1973. For half a century it has been fully integrated into Gaza's social fabric and has run the strip for 16 years. Its defences have been built around—and ;under;—the territory's civilian infrastructure. Part of the ease with which Hamas seized Gaza from Palestinian rivals in 2007 was down to the fact that its fighters were recruited from the streets.

;

;A third difference is tactics. Israel's armed forces say that they place considerable emphasis on civilian protection. Nonetheless, Israel's bombardment of Gaza has been intense by historical standards. It dropped 6,000 bombs on the territory in the first six days of the war, a rate of ordnance far exceeding American and Western counter-terrorism campaigns. In Mosul, for instance, the American-led coalition dropped 7,000 over two months in the most intense period of bombing. On October 30th a former deputy commander of the ;IDF;'s Gaza Division told the ;Financial Times;: “When our soldiers are manoeuvring we are doing this with massive artillery, with 50 aeroplanes overhead destroying anything that moves.”

;

;Tactics are shaped by how an army views the stakes of a war, the nature of the enemy and that of the surrounding civilians. For Israel, the war in Gaza is “existential in a way that even Mosul or Marawi weren't”, says Anthony King of Exeter University, referring to a battle between the Philippines army and ;IS; in 2017. Israeli officials increasingly describe Hamas as akin to ;IS;—an enemy with which compromise is no longer possible. Nor does the ;IDF; have the same affinity with Palestinian civilians that Iraqi forces did with the compatriots they were liberating from ;IS; rule.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In Mosul, Iraq's political leadership, from the prime minister down, insisted that great emphasis be placed on civilian protection. Lieutenant General Basim al-Tai, a senior Iraqi officer, was in charge of the humanitarian operation. “He was carrying the weight of the Mosul population on his shoulders,” says General Jones. “He cared deeply about the civilians.” Caroline Baudot, an adviser in the civilian-protection unit in the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva, agrees: “The commander's intent in Mosul was extremely clear.”

;

;Even then, the experience of different parts of Mosul is instructive. The east of the city, viewed as the more intellectual and urbane part, suffered less damage. The old city in the west, where ;IS; made its last stand, was viewed by Iraqi forces as more conservative and ;IS;-friendly and emerged far worse. “The mindset in which you fight affects your planning, your conduct, and even the reconstruction,” says Ms Baudot. “If you operate on your own territory [as opposed to] in another territory you might not have the same care for civilians.”

;

;The role of medical facilities is especially contentious. In the previous rounds of warfare, Palestinian hospitals and other civilian relief centres were marked on Israeli military maps as non-strike areas. Some were hit in past wars, but none intentionally, claims Israel. In this war, Israel has ordered the evacuation of northern Gaza, including ;hospitals;—which it says are used as Hamas command posts. Under the laws of war, hospitals lose their special protection if they are used for military purposes. But, even then, armies can only attack them “after due warning” and “a reasonable time limit”.

;

;Mosul, again, provides a point of comparison. ;IS; used the city's hospital as a stronghold. Commanders spent weeks deliberating whether it could be attacked, says General Jones, considering other options such as the use of snipers. “Slowly, over time, it became clear it was no longer a functional hospital.” Ultimately it was struck only with the approval of Iraq's then prime minister. “I've never heard of any case where you have a few days to evacuate and dismantle an entire hospital,” says one veteran expert on wartime civilian harm, reflecting on the Gaza case. “It's just not possible.”

;

;A fourth and final difference is the nature of battlefield intelligence. At the outset of this war the ;IDF; would have had considerable intelligence on Hamas's infrastructure in Gaza, collected over years. But many of those targets would have been struck in the first week of the campaign. Air forces must then move to “dynamic” targeting—finding and striking targets that were not known at the start of the war and have to be developed in relatively short order. This is where most cases of civilian harm occur, says the expert.

;

;In Mosul, local civilians, many of whom hated ;IS;, provided a wealth of human intelligence, or ;HUMINT;—information passed on by sources on the ground—to Iraqi forces, helping them to target; IS; fighters. In contrast, during the battle for Raqqa, a Syrian city held by ;IS;, in 2017, commanders, with fewer infantry forces on the ground, were “starved of local information” and found themselves reliant on aerial surveillance, incapable of seeing inside buildings, according to a report by the ;RAND; Corporation, a think-tank.

;

;Israeli intelligence has already suffered one serious intelligence failure in Gaza, having missed sufficient signs of Hamas's preparations for the attack of October 7th. It will have good electronic intelligence on the strip, aided by the phalanx of American aircraft patrolling in the eastern Mediterranean. But Hamas is likely to have the intelligence advantage on the ground, argues Mr Fox, with locals offering a steady flow of ;HUMINT; to the group as the ;IDF; advances. “This flips the ;HUMINT; situation that we saw in Mosul on its head,” he says. “The ;IDF; will have to methodically fight through better planned and prepared defences…than they otherwise would.” The result will be more civilians killed. The last three weeks have been hard on civilians in Gaza. The coming weeks could be even harder. ;■;

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 16:27:03 +0800 Matthew Perry changed the way America spoke | Obituaryhttps://www.economist.com/obituary/2023/11/01/matthew-perry-changed-the-way-america-spoke ;
;
;

;;I;;t is impossible;, now, to watch it in the same way. The emphasis has changed—and emphasis is what matters in comedy. He'd always known that. The words, the sentence, the scene can be the same but alter the emphasis—lean a little harder on this word, push a little on that one—and the joke is transformed. He and his friends had played with this when they were at school. They'd developed their own way of speaking. “Could it ;be; any hotter?” they'd ask. “Could the teacher ;be ;any meaner?” It changed everything.

;

;Emphasis was always his thing—it had got him the part in the first place. Everyone had wanted to be in “Friends Like Us” but in the audition it was he who had nailed it, reading the words in that unexpected way, “hitting emphases that no one else had hit”; making everyone laugh. It was less that he, Matthew Perry, could play Chandler than that he ;was ;Chandler. He changed the part—and then the part changed him. Fame, fortune, money followed. And above all, The Big Terrible Thing. The thing so big, so terrible that it would demand emphatic capitals; cause him to return to rehab 15 times—and change the emphasis of those jokes forever.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Watch “Friends” after everything that happened and suddenly it seemed different: not simply a sitcom but a chronicle of his decline. Take that episode in season three, the one titled “The One With The Hypnosis Tape”. Later people saw it instead as The One Where You Could See How Thin He Was. By then, he was addicted to opioids which had left him vomiting and all but unable to eat. Anyone watching that season should, he thought, be “horrified” by this thinness. Everywhere, hindsight makes the lines land differently. Take that episode in season one, where a shrink turns up and starts to analyse him.; “You're so funny,” the shrink says to Chandler. “I wouldn't want to be there when the laughter stops.”

;

;“Friends” was not how he wanted to be remembered. Though he did definitely want to be remembered—on that he was clear. Before that first audition he'd fallen to his knees, eyes closed. “God, you can do whatever you want to me,” he had prayed. “Just please make me famous.” God seems to have listened, as success on a different scale followed. Ever after he would be a man to be measured in millions: 22m watched the pilot episode. More than 50m watched a single, star-studded episode in series two. By series eight, he was making $1m an episode. “But the Almighty, being the Almighty, had not forgotten the first part of that prayer as well.” He would later spend over $7m in rehab.

;

;But before that there was the success. Which was staggering. “Friends Like Us” became first “Friends” then, for its fans, almost “friends”. Mass television was still consumed en masse then and for a time a whole generation seemed to know which Friend they “were”: the nerdy one (Ross); the pretty one (Rachel)—or the funny one: him. It was less a programme than a paradigm; people started copying everything about them: their hair (“The Rachel cut” was particularly popular); their syntax (the definite article gained a newfound celebrity—“The This”; “The That”). Even English intonation itself bent before the show. It was, he thought, surely not an exaggeration to say that Chandler had changed how America spoke. Could its influence ;be ;any more clear?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And each week, tens of millions of Americans sat on couches to watch the Friends sit on their couches. Which was ironic, in a way, as he had always loathed sitting at home on couches. Performing in front of thousands—that he could do. But put him alone “on my couch in front of a ;TV; for the night and I get scared.” Being on his own had always frightened him. His parents had split up when he was small. When he was five, his mother had put him on a plane, alone, to go and see his father in Los Angeles. He had snacks, and priority boarding, and fancy lounges. He had perks; but no parents. He'd been terrified. Later, as a famous actor, he'd get some of the same airport perks again. He hated them then, too.

;

;In the end, it was alcohol that comforted him. When he was fourteen, he and some friends had got a six-pack of Budweiser and a bottle of white wine. His friends had just got drunk—but he had got a sudden, overwhelming sense of wellbeing. At last, he knew that he was taken care of; at last he knew it was all fine. It was ;bliss;. After that, there were more drugs, more bliss and, after a neck injury, there were opioids. They were better yet: “like replacing your blood with warm honey.”

;

;Then the bliss faded. Watch “Friends” now and you can tell the state of his addictions by his appearance: chunky—that's the alcohol. Skinny—that's pills. The goatee? That was lots of pills. Eventually the opioids would give him such severe constipation that his colon exploded and he passed out. “I was so full of shit it almost killed me.” There was still humour, of a sort. He would later learn that while he was unconscious there had been a debate about whether he should be taken to a different clinic. The different clinic thought not: it apparently took one look at his charts and said: “Matthew Perry is not dying in our hospital.”

;

;It is odd, he later wrote, “to live in a world where if you died, it would shock people but surprise no one.” He was right about the shock. People were often shocked by him. They were shocked when they saw him in life: he looked so old. Those who had watched “Friends” the first time around were shocked afresh when it was re-aired on Netflix in 2015; though this time the shock was not at his age but their own. It all looked so dated: the hair; the ties; the staginess; the whiteness. How had we not realised that we had been living in the past? That time had been passing so quickly? For millions, he became less a man than a memento mori.

;

;Mr Perry himself needed no reminders about death. He had been to death's door, and back. Although that wasn't quite the emphasis he gave it—and for him emphasis, as always, mattered. He had started writing his memoir on his phone; it finally came out last year. And from its first pages it was clear where he wanted to lay the stress. Not on death, after all; but life. “I am alive,” he wrote. “Those three words are more miraculous to me than you might imagine…I am alive.” ;■;

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 16:27:03 +0800 Lab-grown models of embryos increasingly resemble the real thing | Science & technologyhttps://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/11/01/lab-grown-models-of-embryos-increasingly-resemble-the-real-thing ;
;
;

;;T;;he traditional; way to make an embryo is to combine a sperm cell with an egg, often after dinner and a bottle of wine.但一种新的方式可能即将到来。 In recent years scientists have discovered that they can persuade stem cells—those with the ability to transform into many other sorts of cells—to form structures that look and behave very much ;like embryos;.

;

;“Embryoids”, as such creations are called, can help with the study of embryology and pregnancy, and how they can go wrong.有些传真看起来惊人的真实。 In 2022 two teams, one led by Magdalena Zernicka-Goetz, who works at the California Institute of Technology and the University of Cambridge, and another by Jacob Hanna at the Weizmann Institute of Science, in Israel, published papers describing mouse embryoids with ;rudimentary guts, brains and beating hearts;. 6 月，Zernicka-Goetz 博士发表了一篇论文，描述了一种旨在模仿发育最早阶段的人类胚胎，即真正的胚胎植入母亲子宫后不久。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That second study was controversial, with some other scientists dubious that it represented as much of an advance as its authors claimed.但最先进的技术发展得足够快，以至于一些人认为胚状体可能很快就会变得很难与它们要建模的胚胎区分开来。从很多方面来说，这将是一件好事：模型越准确，它就越有用。 Human embryoids could shed light on developmental heart defects or diseases like spina bifida, and boost the success rates of in-vitro fertilisation (;IVF;).

;

;But research on embryos—which, after all, have the potential to develop into human beings—is strictly regulated.许多国家禁止在研究中使用超过 14 天的人类胚胎，而没有此类法律的国家的研究人员通常会自愿遵守相同的标准。胚状体与真实事物越相似，就越难避免它们是否应该遵守类似规则的问题。

;

;A natural embryo begins with a single fertilised egg.为了制造胚状体，科学家们培养了来自胚胎或有时来自成体生物体的不同干细胞的混合物。他们可能会调整细胞之间的分子信号以及哪些基因处于活跃状态。几天之内，胚胎样结构就出现了。

;

;Embryoids are desirable partly because real embryos are scarce: the main source is leftovers from ;IVF; treatment.它们也很难生长。这使得进行大规模实验变得棘手。胚胎提供了一种道德问题较少的替代方案。

;

;A rose by any other name

;

;One example of their benefits is the study of implantation, the process by which an embryo implants into the womb.大多数流产都是在这里发生的。但在胚状体出现之前，几乎不可能详细研究其原因。 “你无法通过母亲的身体来观察胚胎的发育，”泽尼卡-戈茨博士说。

;

;Embryoids—specifically, a type called a blastoid—offer the next-best thing.它们首先由奥地利科学院的尼古拉斯·里夫龙 (Nicolas Rivron) 创建，类似于植入前的胚泡阶段的胚胎。在人类中，植入发生在第七天左右，而在小鼠中，植入发生在第四天左右。每个胚泡都由一个空心的细胞球组成，在真正的胚胎中，这些细胞球会继续成为胎盘的一部分。附着在内壁上的是一个较小的球，在其他情况下，它会发育成胎儿。 By rolling blastoids across uterine tissue in a dish, Dr Rivron's team found that they only stick when they are oriented so that this inner mass is closest to the womb tissue.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That implies the inner mass sends signals to the outer cells, instructing them to stick to the womb.里夫龙博士认为他已经识别了这些信号，并计划很快公布他的结果。他希望帮助解释为什么这么多胚胎无法着床。 That might, in turn, improve the success rates of ;IVF;, which in America is only about 35%. Rivron 博士说，Blastoids 使此类发现变得更加容易。他创办了一家名为 Dawn Bio 的公司，该公司利用胚泡来筛选可能对生育治疗有用的候选药物。

;

;Other embryoids try to capture what embryos look like after implantation.最先进的是用小鼠干细胞制成的，例如上面描述的大脑和心脏模型，它代表小鼠发育的第八天。汉纳博士保持着人类胚胎的记录。在 9 月份发表的一篇论文中，他和他的同事描述了模仿人类胚胎在第 8 天到第 14 天发育的拟胚体。他热衷于尝试将事情推得更远，也许到第 35 天。那时，他的拟胚体就像老鼠一样那些，将开始发育器官。

;

;Dr Hanna believes that could make them a source of medically useful cells.例如，它们可能提供干细胞，这些干细胞又可以转化为骨髓，用于白血病患者的移植。如果用于产生胚状体的干细胞取自患者，那么骨髓在基因上将与患者自己的骨髓相同。这将消除免疫排斥的风险，以及对免疫抑制药物的需求。

;

;Convincing the embryoids to develop still further might open up truly mind-bending possibilities.从第 50 天左右开始，胚状体就会有性腺。这可能意味着，有一天，那些努力怀孕的女性可以得到一套全新的、新鲜出炉的自己的鸡蛋。 (Dr Hanna's company, Renewal Bio, is pursuing such goals.)

;

;No one knows when—or even if—these goals might be achieved.伦敦弗朗西斯·克里克研究所 (Francis Crick Institute) 的发育生物学家内奥米·莫里斯 (Naomi Moris) 也认为汉纳博士的 14 天大胚胎看起来很合适。但她认为他们还没有资格成为完全替代者。一方面，汉纳博士的胚胎从未经历过囊胚样阶段。 That missing link prevents them from attaching to a natural womb, and might impose limits on how long they can carry on developing in a dish.

;

;Still, the fact that such goals are being pursued at all has convinced some scientists that the time to think about regulation is now.莫里斯博士提出了胚胎的新法律定义，该定义将基于胚胎发育成胎儿的潜力，胎儿的发育阶段从受精后八周开始一直持续到出生。在许多国家，人类胚胎的法律定义不明确。莫里斯博士希望她的提议能够明确表明，如果拟胚体具有相同的发育潜力，那么它就可以成为胚胎。

;

;Working out if they do, though, might be tricky.确定胚胎是否能发育成胎儿的唯一方法就是尝试一下——尽管如果成功的话，这样的实验可能会面临违法的风险。 Instead Dr Moris and her colleagues, including Dr Rivron, have suggested a two-part test that would make at least a compelling argument that embryoids had closed the gap.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The first step would be to check just how closely human embryoids track the developmental trajectory of real embryos.第二个是尽可能地推动动物胚胎，理想情况下达到产生活的、可育后代的程度。这样的过程可能会从小鼠开始，然后再转移到猪或猴子身上。如果这种长期发育的胚状体在生化上看起来与人类最先进的技术相似，那么就需要谨慎对待。

;

;Dr Moris reckons that, within two to five years, someone will have produced animal embryoids that can reach the fetal stage. 4月，中国研究人员将猴子胚芽移植到代孕动物体内，产生了持续长达20天的妊娠。而且总是有可能有人变得流氓。 2018年，中国研究人员贺建奎宣布他已经创造出基因编辑的人类婴儿。他被判入狱，并受到广泛谴责。但有人可能会尝试以类似的方式利用胚胎来突破界限，这并非不可想象。

;

;Pushing the limits

;

;Amander Clark, the president of the International Society for Stem Cell Research, highlights another irony that could make regulation difficult.由于人类胚胎的培养时间不能超过 14 天，因此科学家们无法详细了解它们随后如何发育。这使得判断 14 天以上的胚状体是否表现出应有的行为变得非常困难。唯一的比较是动物胚胎和通过手术从孕妇身上取出的子宫解剖。换句话说，这条旨在保护胚胎的规则意味着研究人员可能很难判断他们的替代方案是否足够好，或者好到应该获得法律保护。 ;■;
